pages.title: ⤝ King of Swords ⤝
pages.text: King of the Chariots of Wind$(br)        $(m)∆$() Air of $(m)∆$() Air

A crowned man sits upon his throne, facing forward as if ready to confront whatever life throws at him.$(br)  He sits in judgment, holding the unsheathed weapon of his suit.$(br)  The back of his throne is decorated with a butterfly, hinting at transformation and liberty of thought.$(br)  The wind is calm and the clouds shift slowly in gentle movement; a symbol of his calm decisiveness and intellectual understanding.

If nothing else, he is the master of intellect and of laws; laws of the mind and inner laws of creation.$(br)  Though he may honor justice, he represents in truth the power to life and death. Knights use their Swords for service, Kings use them for power.$(br)  He fitfully takes to the side of conquest in dedication to battle and empire, evoking this suit's side of conflict, anger, and pain; dire consequences of purely intellectual

demonstrations of power.$(br2)$(l)Divinatory meanings$()$(br)  Judgment, command, militant intelligence.$(br)  May mean someone in a position of authority, a powerful intellect; or someone who has fought plenty in life.$(br2)$(l)Reversed$()$(br)  Perversity, inconsistency, fanaticism.$(br) May mean someone aggressive, who uses fighting to gain control of others.
